author: Megan Davies
title: Sky Sports pundit Gary Neville gives Manchester's homeless blessing to stay in £1.5m hotel this winter - Showbiz
text: Sky Sports pundit Gary Neville has given his blessing to the homeless squatters who have taken up residence in his new hotel and allowed them to stay in the building during the winter.Former Manchester United star Neville and hotel co-owner Ryan Giggs have received planning permission to transform Manchester's historic stock exchange into a new boutique hotel, but the building was sitting empty as the footballers planned for extensive renovations to take place before opening. Housing activists occupied the site on Saturday (October 17). © Jo Hale/Redferns via Getty Images Wesley Hall, leader of housing activists Manchester Angels, told the Manchester Evening News that he was left "crying and shaking" after talking to Neville on Sunday."What a great guy Gary Neville is," Hall said. "We've been in negotiations with him and things are looking good. He said the main building work isn't taking place until February, so we'll be okay to stay until then."(function(d, s, id) { var js, fjs = d.getElementsByTagName(s)[0]; if (d.getElementById(id)) return; js = d.createElement(s); js.id = id; js.src = "//connect.facebook.net/en_GB/sdk.js#xfbml=1&version=v2.3"; fjs.parentNode.insertBefore(js, fjs);}(document, 'script', 'facebook-jssdk'));I'm crying...Just go off the phone to Gary Neville...He's letting us stay for a few months over the winter period and he's gonna help us with intervention I'm shaking here.#TheGraftPaysOff Posted by Manchester Angels on Sunday, 18 October 2015Hall added: "I'm just in shock. He's such an amazing guy. He told me he's always tried to help out homeless people in Manchester, but wanted to do more."He knows we'll look after the building and make proper use of it until the building work starts. This isn't a long-term thing, but we'll have so much going on in here to help people."It's exactly what Manchester needs right now."Neville bought the building with Giggs two years ago for a reported £1.5 million, and the new development will contain 35 bedrooms, plus a private members' club, gym and rooftop bar.Manchester Angels plans to set up a kitchen at the building offering hot meals, and have also said they will provide practical support for the city's homeless including health checkups, benefits advice and workshops to help homeless people secure jobs and permanent accommodation.On Neville's part, The Guardian reports that he sees this act as an extension of the support he's offered to homeless people over the last 10 years, saying: "From my point of view, I'm quite relaxed about this."Neville and Giggs will feature alongside fellow Manchester United teammates Phil Neville, Paul Scholes and Nicky Butt in a new spinoff documentary series Class of 92: Out of Their League on BBC One later this month.The two-part series charts the former footballers as they took over control of local club Salford City FC last season.
